Exploring Native American Quilting Aesthetics

Data Analysis + Visualization + Interaction Design

Interactive Visualization

Overview

Project Inception

Quilts were first introduced to Native American or Indian communities by European settlers seeking to "civilize" them through European home-making skills. However, these indigenous communities were intrigued by the bed coverings and made them their own by incorporating their cultural aesthetic and stories through symbolism and patterns into their quilts. Within the community, quilts today are considered quintessentially Native, but people hardly know of their striking art form outside of it.
In addition, ethnographers of the late 1800's were interested in documenting parts of the culture untouched by European influence, thus portraying a stereotypical image of the Native American people as pure and primitive. They failed to recognize that the community was changing, and while the quilt on its own may not be unique, it gives a glimpse into the community's belief system and worldview.

Role

Data Analyst

Final Report Video of Visualization

Research

  • Background Research

Research

Research Questions

  1. How have quilting aesthetics evolved through time across Native American tribes?
  2. Are there any visual relationships in quilting aesthetics, specifically in color and motifs across various Native American tribes and cultures beyond?
  3. Using generative technology, how might we explore alternate quilting aesthetics or new, hypothetical forms of connection between tribes?

Project Aim

  • To help people discover, appreciate, and celebrate the indigenous art tradition of Native American people's relationship to quilts/quilting culture.
  • Understand the influence of other cultures on Native American quilting aesthetics. While the common perception is that Native American tribes are insular, this project contests that claim.
  • Daylight cultural appropriation over time - exploring alternative aesthetic possibilities and interconnectedness from traditions that grow from each other, learn, and depart or come together.

Value Systems

Our process and outcome were embedded in a clear set of values that aided decision-making and served as a moral compass for the project. As we were working with unstructured, image-based data in the realm of indigenous craft, documenting and making our process open-source was as important to us as our final product to enable others to build on our work.

Process Value System

Participatory: Having little to no exposure to Native American history, culture, and quilt making, we collaborated with several experts in the field to guide our project focus, research questions, and final outcome.

Accuracy: As Native American quilting is not a well-documented folk art form, not all research and data sources were reliable. We adopted a strict and rigorous process to fact-check our research with experts and designed ways to navigate any corruption in the data.

Project Value System

Self-initiated learning: Our tool is designed to be more exploratory over explanatory, discovery-led, and promotes self-initiated learning.

Sensitive: As Native American tribes are our primary subject, our tool aims to ensure that the final product is sensitive to their history, culture, and tradition.

Transparent: To enable others to build on our work, we will make our data sources, process, and created datasets openly available. We also understand that our datasets are not perfect and thus wish to provide an open platform for members of the community or experts to correct any of the work we have put out. We are also transparent about the representation of tribes within the data, making our biases aware and known.

Problem

As we dove deeper into the story of Native American quilting culture to develop research questions, a few challenges were apparent to us almost instantly:

  • Few credible online resources on Native American Quilting culture
  • Discrepancy in the information presented in online resources

We addressed these challenges by referring to physical books from Harvard libraries and consulting with experts on the information and insights we derived throughout the process.

Due to the nuance in Native American culture and history and our responsibility to represent them accurately, our research phase extended throughout the design process.

Online Resources and Books on Native American Quilting Culture

Discrepancy in Information Across Different Sources and Key Findings from Expert Interviews

Key Research Findings

General Information
  • The lack of documented evidence obscures the history of American quilts prior to 1750.
  • At significant milestones in community life, such as the birth of a baby, weddings, or when a triumphant warrior returned, star quilts were gifted. Morning Star quilts were draped over caskets at funerals and passed from one family to another in giving ceremonies. Quilts were also designed to make political statements.
  • Textile scraps and rug scraps were initially used to make quilts.
Influence
  • Quilts were found not only in the colder latitudes where the English, Dutch, and Welsh settled down and brought a tradition of quilting with them but also spread and adopted by communities with no quilting heritage or functional need for quilts. Quilts are ubiquitous in America and a mode of creative expression.
  • Native American quilting aesthetics have roots in non-native communities such as New England, England, and India.
  • Quilt-making was introduced to Native communities primarily by Indian boarding schools to Native children to enact Western assimilation.
  • Tribes that moved together, have common ancestors, and were known to be enemies or allies during a specific period may have shared knowledge on quilting.
  • Knowledge was shared from one generation to another through women in quilting bees (community groups during quilt-making sessions). During these sessions, the women could talk freely about a breadth of topics, from housekeeping tips to political views.
Color and Symbolism
  • Experimentation with synthetic dyes in the 1900's led to a more diverse color palette.
  • The colors and symbols featured on Native American quilts represent their cultural identity. Color significance, symbolism, and names given to these symbols vary across communities.
  • Native American tribes have reused patterns used in traditional artifacts such as hyde paintings, buffalo robes, and tipis (conical tents made of skins, cloth, or canvas on a frame of poles) on quilts.
  • Tribes are inspired by nature and incorporate natural elements into their design.

Define

Stakeholders

# Stakeholders Description
1 General Audience Curious to learn about Native American quilting culture; Get an overview of the quilting culture; Get a tactile and visual feel for the art form; Get an intimate look into the art form.
2 Educators/Curators Accurate and honest representation of data that is sensitive to the culture and art form; Value self-initiated exploration and discovery.
3 Native Americans Accurate and honest inferences that are backed by data that is sensitive to the culture and art form.

While we had a general idea of our audience at the start of the project, research with experts helped us be more specific about our project stakeholders, their needs, and the purpose of our tool.

Stakeholder Needs Product-level Considerations
Curious to learn about Native American quilting culture; Get an overview of the quilting culture. Clear introduction to Native American tribes, clarify jargon, provide an overview and opportunities to engage at a deeper level voluntarily.
Get a tactile and visual feel for the art form; Get an intimate look into the art form. At any point, while exploring, users can click on a quilt and choose to examine it more closely through the zoom-in feature and learn more about the artist, history, and influences of that particular quilt.
Accurate and honest representation of data that is sensitive to the culture and art form Cite all sources on the product and add a note on the distribution of data on a tribe level; Steer clear from making any generalized claims about Native American culture as a whole.

Data Preperation

Data Acquisition

As we aimed to study aesthetics and visual relationships, we focused on image databases. We reached out far and wide for datasets - including relevant university departments, heritage centers, missionary boarding schools, world-renowned and community museums, and more.

Challenges
  • Lack of image databases focused on Native American quilts
  • Inequality in the type of tribes represented in Native American quilts datasets
  • Lack of structured image datasets with consistent attributes

Data Cleaning

After careful research, we decided to collect data through webscraping and utilizing API from Quilt Index, International Quilt Museum, and Smithsonian Institute. The consistency of attributes varied across each source (consistent, mostly consistent, inconsistent).

Consistent Attributes: Date, location (city, state, and country), period, dimensions, technique, primary fabric, and fiber
Mostly Consistent Attributes: Tribe
Inconsistent Attributes: Quilt maker's name and essay/history about the quilt

After 3-4 weeks of search, we decided to narrow down on those attributes consistent across images, clearly call out the tribes represented, and steer clear from making generalized inferences about Native American quilting culture as a whole.

Challenges
  • Lack of well-documented images of quilts
  • Diverse quilt patterns

To address the above, we created 14 color buckets based on prevalence to categorize all our colors. All the images of quilts were then cropped using edge detection, and colors were clustered to extract the percentage of usage in each quilt. The colors were then grouped into the closest color bucket.

Definition for the finding the closest color

Extracting colors and clustering them with percentages

The color extraction was completed after multiple rounds of trial and error with different codes and varying levels of accuracy.

We then organized the color data in our excel sheet in the form of hex codes and used a code to view the color filled into each cell. Our initial dataset had colors organized per quilt. In order to create our alluvial diagram, we had to consolidate colors across quilts into a single column.

We also referred to maps, researched tribe-specific websites to identify their dominant landscape, and categorized the tribe based on their surrounding landscape.

Ideation + Design

Visualization Exploration

Before inputting the collected data, we created drafts of color exploration pages by landscapes and locations to determine how to bucket colors in a digestible number.

Concept Drafts of Color Explorations By Landscapes

Concept Drafts of Color Explorations By Locations

Alluvial Diagram of Color Categories and Explorations

Color Extractions According to the Timeline

Methodology

We used RAWGraphs to prototype our data visualization and draw inferences. We designed different prototypes of visualizing the same dataset - enabling us to choose the visualization that would be the easiest to understand and draw inferences from. The RAWGraphs visualizations were exported to Figma and further refined.

The Alluvial diagram and area chart allowed users to perceive different colors. However, to reduce clutter, we could remove the names of the specific tribes and retain the landscape name and color palette. The names of the specific tribes could be revealed upon hovering over the various types of landscapes.

Too many tribes would distract the user from making necessary inferences. Thus we chose to only focus on our majority representation.

Exploring Colors Across Quilts

Implementation of Real Data

Exploring Influence Across Quilts

To represent evolution and relationships, we explored a comparative view of quilts from two tribes and a timeline view to show the evolution of the floral pattern in Native Hawaiian Quilts. However, we needed a solution combining the two views into one and more scalable as a system.

Color Categories and Explorations

Color Extractions According to the Timeline

Color Extractions According to the Timeline

Color Usage Across Tribes

Color Usage Across Landscapes

Key Design Considerations for “Exploring Color Across Quilts” Alluvial Diagram
  • Use dashed lines in the visualization rather than solid ones to indicate a thread-like texture, reduce the intensity of each color, and make all colors easily comprehensible.
  • Place the US map right next to the names of the tribes for better readability.
Key Design Considerations for “Exploring Symbolism Across Quilts” Chart
  • Highlight critical historical events to contextualize the information presented.
  • Use perspective or a 3D space-like feel to make the user feel like they are moving through space and time to view the quilts.
  • Avoid using color as a legend because analysis of color is one of our main views and thus will only confuse people.

Generative Model Implementation

How might we explore new forms of interconnectedness between communities that are enabled by technology?

We wanted to be intentional about our research questions and looked at historical relationships between different tribes to inform the datasets we fed into our tool. I used StyleGAN and RunwayML to explore the similarities between tribes. After exploring, we decided to explore the knowledge exchange between the Hopi tribe, known for embracing peace, and the Sioux, the warrior tribes.

StyleGAN Trained Model on All Quilts

StyleGAN Trained Model on Quilts of Hopi and Sioux Tribes
